creditline: Gift of Mary and Bob Mersky
description: black gessoed paper with visible brushstrokes and satin finish; twenty silver-black cubes layered across each other in random pattern; some edges of cubes and most places where cubes touch have charred appearance, with layers of gesso visible; in some places browned gesso or paper layers are visible; in twelve places small holes visible in middle of charred areas
medium: Graphite on black gessoed paper, with scorching from 15,000 volt electrical current
provenance: The artist, Minneapolis; [Yossi Milo Gallery, New York, sold to Mersky 2018]; Robert B. Mersky, Minneapolis; given to MIA, 2020.
text: Part art, part science, David Goldes’ recent series of abstract geometric drawings relies on the conductive properties of graphite as a critical feature of their creation. In this example, Goldes forms the primary composition by applying numerous layers of graphite on paper prepared with a black gesso (diluted plaster) ground. Leaving small gaps between the thick graphite elements, he then applies a 15,000-volt electric current to one side of the drawing. As the electricity reaches a gap, the current arcs and scorches or even burns the paper, leaving distinctive marks that add an intriguing element of chance to the drawing process.
